channel.title: System.out Problem
channel.description:
i was unsure if this is even possible, but i want to be able to do
print("Loaded" + completed + "/300");
then erase that line next once the next thing has completed
PseudoCode [code] BEGIN WHILE completed NOT EQUAL 300 THEN erase_last_Line print("Loaded" & completed & "/300") END WHILE END [/code]
JavaPseudo [code] public void run(){ while(completed != 300){ eraseLastLine(); out.print("Loaded" + completed + "/300") } } [/code]
so instead of spamming window it just uses same line

[quote=“BAsh(CntLgn), post:6, topic:206523”][quote author=k00dr link=topic=272344.msg2231148#msg2231148 date=1211145666]
You need to give them an example, frank_ 

for(int i = 0; i <= 100; i++) {
  System.out.print('\r'); //back to the beginning of current line
  System.out.print(i + "%");
  Thread.sleep(10);
}

[/quote]
Fails for me. (Eclipse)[/quote]

So what you’re saying is, that Eclipse fails

item.title: System.out Problem
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

System.out doesn’t necessarily mean it goes to a console, only to “standard out”
what happens if stdout is redirected to a file, or piped to another process? this System.out.clear() makes no sense in that situation.

i know you can do what you’re asking with cmd.exe and win32 api, and with that Konsole in KDE

but java is meant to be cross platform, so anyone who implements a jvm needs to go around to every console program and write the code for it separately, it would just be too annoying and noone would do it,

just use a GUI if you want it to look nice,
if you don’t mind, just make it print “Doing work…” before you start, then println “Finished” when you’re done

although for some reason, i seem to remember frank_'s updater from a long time ago, it did something like this while downloading the client,
maybe I’m remembering it wrong though

Read full topic

item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

There isn’t a clear() method somewhere? I know C#'s System.Console class has a Clear() method which does exactly what you described.

Read full topic

@frank wrote:

you are using a carriage return, it is and always has been \r

item.title: System.out Problem
item.dc:creator: @shangtsung1 shangtsung1
item.description:
@shangtsung1 wrote:

i was unsure if this is even possible, but i want to be able to do

print(“Loaded” + completed + “/300”);

then erase that line next once the next thing has completed

PseudoCode

BEGIN
  WHILE completed NOT EQUAL 300 THEN
     erase_last_Line
     print("Loaded" & completed & "/300")
  END WHILE
END

JavaPseudo

public void run(){
   while(completed != 300){
     eraseLastLine();
     out.print("Loaded" + completed + "/300")
   }
}

so instead of spamming window it just uses same line

Read full topic
